summary: Herbert Itkin was a person of interest to the CIA and FBI due to alleged Mafia connections, espionage activities, and claims of providing information to U.S. intelligence. He was a former employee of both the CIA and FBI. Documents indicate investigations into his background, travel restrictions in Santo Domingo, and his past associations. He claimed CIA involvement and connections to Allen Dulles. The CIA used him as an informant on Haitian exiles. He later attempted to involve the CIA in a custody battle, exposing CIA agent Bernard E. Moncure. Australian Justice A.R. Moffitt requested information on Itkin for an inquiry into organized crime in New South Wales, seeking details on his reliability and status between 1964 and 1969. The CIA provided Moffitt with publicly available affidavits related to Itkin's affiliation with the CIA.
significance: The documents suggest Herbert Itkin was a person with connections to intelligence agencies and organized crime, whose reliability and activities were questioned and investigated by multiple agencies. His claims of CIA involvement and connections to Allen Dulles, along with his use as an informant and subsequent attempts to involve the CIA in personal matters, made him a subject of interest and concern to the CIA. The documents do not directly link him to the JFK assassination, but his connections to intelligence agencies and alleged Mafia ties could potentially be relevant in a broader investigation.
